evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
roots_spec.statement: Primary pushback control lapse: active tug instructor failed to stop at TRP. NEC: The required TRP stop/release point was reached but not complied with; Pushback movement continued beyond TRP until blast-fence contact

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
roots_spec.statement: Primary coordination failure: challenge/alert breakdown among ground crew. NEC: Crew held divergent assumptions about stop-state or intent; No timely effective challenge or stop warning occurred despite cues

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
roots_spec.statement: Primary environmental/marking deficiency at TRP. NEC: TRP marking visibility/prominence/placement was inadequate; The marking deficiency plausibly caused or materially enabled the TRP miss

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
roots_spec.statement: Primary mechanical or control-system failure. NEC: A tug or aircraft control/braking malfunction affected stopping; Corroboration exists via tests, diagnostics, or repeat failures

slot_statements.availability: The primary coordination failure involving challenge/alert breakdown among ground crew was consistently present during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, as evidenced by the historical data and interim reports.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identified coordination failure withstands alternative explanations, as no other factors sufficiently account for the lack of effective challenge or stop warnings, confirming the root cause's validity.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The root cause aligns with key features of the incident, including divergent assumptions about stop-state or intent among crew members and the absence of timely, effective challenge or stop warnings despite available cues.

slot_statements.availability: The primary pushback control lapse involving the active tug instructor failing to stop at the TRP is documented and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, within the hist_t2_interim scope.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The root cause is resistant to defeaters as the evidence clearly shows the tug instructor's failure to stop at the TRP despite reaching the required point, with no alternative explanations or mitigating factors identified.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: This root cause fits key features including the non-compliance with the required TRP stop/release point and the continuation of pushback movement beyond the TRP until blast-fence contact, matching the procedural deviation described.

node.statement: The primary coordination failure involving challenge/alert breakdown among ground crew was consistently present during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, as evidenced by the historical data and interim reports.

assumptions: The absence of warnings from wingman or headset operator implies a failure in challenge/alert communication.
The continued movement beyond the TRP despite cues indicates coordination failure rather than mechanical or marking issues.
defeaters: If evidence showed timely and effective challenge or stop warnings were given and understood before the TRP exceedance.
If hardware or procedural deviations were the primary cause rather than communication breakdown.

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Direct evidence (H8, H4) shows no timely effective challenge or stop warning despite cues and the aircraft moving beyond the TRP, supporting the claim of primary coordination failure involving challenge/alert breakdown among ground crew.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Potential ambiguity in the extent of communication failure versus procedural deviations; limited detail on exact communication exchanges.

node.statement: The root cause aligns with key features of the incident, including divergent assumptions about stop-state or intent among crew members and the absence of timely, effective challenge or stop warnings despite available cues.

assumptions: Assuming that absence of warnings from wingman and headset operator implies ineffective challenge or alert breakdown.
Assuming that continued movement beyond TRP despite cues indicates divergent assumptions about stop-state or intent.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, timely warnings were given and ignored, or if mechanical or environmental factors were primary causes, this would change the assessment.

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
He suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8 directly supports the claim of failure to challenge or stop warnings despite cues, and H4 shows the aircraft exceeded the TRP, consistent with divergent assumptions about stop-state. H1 and H2 establish crew roles and actions, supporting the coordination failure narrative.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Potential ambiguity in the sufficiency of visual signals and the exact timing of warnings; no direct evidence of crew verbal communication about stop-state assumptions.

slot_statements.availability: The primary environmental or marking deficiency at TRP was present and observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t2_interim timeframe, confirming its availability as a contributing factor.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: No credible evidence or alternative explanations effectively refute the role of the TRP marking deficiency in causing or materially enabling the TRP miss during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t2_interim period.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The identified deficiency in TRP marking visibility, prominence, and placement aligns with the key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t2_interim data, supporting its relevance to the TRP miss.

node.statement: The primary environmental or marking deficiency at TRP was present and observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t2_interim timeframe, confirming its availability as a contributing factor.

assumptions: The TRP marking visibility and placement as described in H7 is representative of the actual conditions during the incident timeframe.
The tug instructor's statements in H8 accurately reflect the limitations of visual signals and situational awareness.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP marking was clearly visible and adequate and the crew recognized it but failed to stop due to procedural or communication failures, this would favor alternative causes.
If mechanical control failures were documented, that would reduce the role of marking deficiency.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7 shows the TRP marking and clearance were defined and adequate, while H8 indicates limitations in visual stop signals and lack of warnings, supporting that marking deficiency was present and observable, confirming availability as a contributing factor.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether marking visibility alone caused the miss versus crew attention or communication failures

slot_statements.availability: The primary mechanical or control-system failure is consistently detectable and reproducible in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the 12-25 hist_t2_interim period, confirmed by tests, diagnostics, or repeat failures.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The conclusion of a primary mechanical or control-system failure is robust against alternative explanations, supported by corroborative evidence from tests, diagnostics, and repeat failure occurrences within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t2_interim scope.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The failure aligns with key features of tug or aircraft control/braking malfunctions affecting stopping, as observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the specified scope.

node.statement: The primary pushback control lapse involving the active tug instructor failing to stop at the TRP is documented and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25, within the hist_t2_interim scope.

assumptions: The tug instructor was in control and aware of the TRP location.
No mechanical faults prevented stopping at the TRP.
Communication and visual signals were insufficient but present.
defeaters: If evidence showed a mechanical failure preventing stopping at TRP or confirmed communication breakdown preventing awareness of TRP stop state, this would change the conclusion.
If TRP markings or environment were proven inadequate to the extent that the instructor could not reasonably be expected to stop, this would favor R3.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 directly documents the pushback continuing beyond the TRP until collision, with H3 and H8 supporting the active role of the tug instructor and lack of effective communication or warning, favoring the procedural deviation hypothesis (R1) over alternatives.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence of mechanical failure or communication breakdown was found; assumptions about instructor awareness and control are based on indirect inference.

node.statement: The primary mechanical or control-system failure is consistently detectable and reproducible in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the 12-25 hist_t2_interim period, confirmed by tests, diagnostics, or repeat failures.

assumptions: No explicit test or diagnostic evidence was provided in the history items
The collision was due to procedural or communication failures rather than mechanical faults
defeaters: If tests or diagnostics confirm a reproducible mechanical or control-system failure during the period
If repeat failures or fault codes are documented supporting mechanical/control failure
If physical evidence of malfunction is found in the tug or aircraft control systems

However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H4) shows the aircraft passed the TRP and collided with the blast barrier despite engine idle, indicating no mechanical/control failure causing stopping issues. Multiple history items (H1, H2, H3, H8, H9) indicate procedural and communication factors rather than mechanical faults. No tests, diagnostics, or repeat failures are reported to confirm mechanical/control failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: absence of direct mechanical/control failure evidence; reliance on procedural and communication history
